awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Automated Speech Therapy Through Speech Recognition with Error Identification
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve outcomes for individuals with speech sound disorders (SSD) by increasing access to care through technology augmented speech therapy. Approximately 5% of children have a SSD, which places them at risk for reading difficulties and processing challenges into adulthood. Speech therapy services are needed to create changes in speech production skills for improved intelligibility and interaction in functional activities of daily living.  However, less than 70% of children receive therapy due to difficulty with accessing care and cost. This project develops artificial intelligence that can recreate the feedback decisions that a speech-language pathologist makes in a live therapy setting. This technology can then be applied to computer- and tablet-delivered speech therapy. Because of the automation, the cost of receiving services can be drastically reduced and children currently without access can get high quality automated therapy at home. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop machine learning algorithms capable of speech sound error identification for the purposes of automating speech therapy. Advances in Automatic Speech Recognition technology have led to the exploration of harnessing artificial intelligence as an aspect of technology-assisted endeavors in speech sound error treatment. However, reliability of the existing technology in its application to speech therapy is poor due to inadequate databases of impaired pediatric speech. The objectives of this study are to: 1) Build a database of impaired and accurate productions of the eight English consonants most commonly in error; 2) use this database to develop and train algorithms for identifying specific errors of segmented target phonemes; and 3) complete inter-rater reliability tests of the trained algorithm with decisions from trained speech-language pathologists to ensure adequate agreement of presence of error and error type. By creating a novel training database and algorithm that has the ability to accomplish these types of tasks, artificial intelligence can advance to recreate the error-specific discrimination and feedback decisions that a speech-language pathologist makes in a live therapy setting, serving as a critically needed tool for addressing the barriers to engaging in adequately frequent speech sound production practice sessions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Public Outcomes Report: Enhancing Speech Sound Analysis for Improved Communication 

  

We are excited to share the outcomes and findings from our project that aimed to revolutionize speech sound analysis and its impact on effective communication. Over the course of this award's duration, we embarked on a journey to leverage cutting-edge technology, innovative game-based interventions, and machine learning algorithms to address the challenges faced by individuals with speech sound disorders. 

 

Innovative Game-Based Interventions: One of the cornerstones of our project was the creation of a novel game, Screech, designed to enhance user engagement and facilitate effective data collection. This engaging game utilized voice-powered echolocation, enabling users to navigate through captivating adventures. Our commitment to privacy and security was paramount, reflected in our incorporation of HIPAA and COPAA compliance features, including a verifiable parental consent system. To foster self-evaluation, we introduced a unique self-grading feature that allowed users to assess their performance. This innovation was subsequently integrated into all our games, enhancing user experience and driving improved outcomes. 

 

Unforeseen Gains: The "Screech Effect": Beyond our initial objectives, we observed an unexpected yet significant phenomenon – the "Screech Effect." This serendipitous discovery led to increased practice repetitions among our existing clients who engaged with our older games. This unforeseen outcome underscored the heightened engagement and efficacy of our gaming interventions, offering anecdotal evidence of our project's positive impact. 

 

Empowering Education and Collaboration: Our partnership with California State University San Marcos (CSUSM) and Dr. Alison Scheer-Cohen brought an educational dimension to our project. We provided speech error discrimination training to CSUSM speech pathology students through our custom portal. This collaboration extended the impact of our work into the educational domain, with student raters contributing over 350 hours of valuable listening time. This collaboration not only enhanced the training of future speech-language pathologists but also underlined the potential of technology to bridge academia and practical application. 

 

Advancing Error Identification Algorithms: Central to our project's technical objectives was the development of error identification algorithms. Our machine learning pipeline processed and integrated data from our gaming interventions into a comprehensive labeling portal. This infrastructure allowed for efficient data collection and storage, facilitating the evaluation of our software's performance against certified speech-language pathologists' judgments. These efforts culminated in significant progress, with our algorithms achieving binary error detection accuracies as high as 81% and a 3-category classification accuracy of up to 75%. 

 

Setting the Stage for Phase II: As we conclude this award's phase, we stand at the threshold of a new endeavor – Phase II. Building upon our achievements, Phase II's technical objectives include targeted data collection, refined error identification algorithms, and real-time feedback mechanisms. Our collaboration with Dr. Scheer-Cohen ensures a multidisciplinary approach that merges clinical expertise with technological innovation. 

 

In summary, our project has yielded a suite of accomplishments that bridge the gap between technology and speech-language pathology. We have pioneered game-based interventions, harnessed machine learning for error identification, and sparked educational collaboration. The "Screech Effect" and unexpected user engagement have further validated the potential of our interventions. With Phase II on the horizon, we are poised to deepen our impact, enhance our tools, and continue transforming the landscape of speech sound analysis for the betterment of communication and lives. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Michael Young

  • Screenshot of Screech Video Game.

    Michael Young
